Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: Tonight, my phone buzzes with a message from my younger sister: “Movie night with everyone at 7? You’re coming, right?” I know how much these evenings mean to her. She’s been trying to pull me out of my shell, hoping we’ll share more than just a roof. I want to be the brother she can count on, the one who shows up, laughs, and makes memories. But tonight is also the community Quran study circle. They’re discussing verses I haven’t read yet, and I promised myself I’d be more committed—reciting, reflecting, and growing in my faith. The group expects me there, and I expect it of myself too. My heart tugs in two directions: the warmth of family, the pull of faith. I stare at my phone, torn, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which part of me should take the lead tonight.
